result.text:
“In the first month after my diagnosis, I was convinced I’d find a cure. I figured that, if anyone could do it, it would be me.”

Cai Lei, the former vice president of e-commerce giant https://t.co/wjeqVCRAlX was told he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) about four years ago. Although it brought an abrupt end to his time in the C-suite, he’s continued to work — or “fight,” as he puts it — from morning to night. Only instead of growing profits, his sole mission now is finding new and effective treatments for his condition.

Read more: https://t.co/ydmhmDCPGp

result.text:
A deadly break period stampede at a middle school in central China killed one student and injured five others this week, bringing renewed scrutiny to China’s overpacked, tightly managed class schedules.

In part, the problem is due to many schools’ unreasonable approach to student safety, says Chu Zhaohui, a researcher at the China National Academy of Educational Sciences.

“In many cases, front-line teachers don’t have the authority needed to handle the responsibilities they’re saddled with,” Chu told Sixth Tone Wednesday. “Their responsibilities and rights are inconsistent, so there is no other solution except strict controls (on students).”

🔗https://t.co/mvAlZ9AlvM

result.text:
When was the last time you cleaned your apartment? In one southwestern Chinese village, the wrong answer could get you fined. Puji Town New Village, in a remote corner of Sichuan, made headlines this week for promising to fine its untidier residents. The punishments, which ranged from three to 20 yuan ($0.40 to $2.75), could be levied for anything from dirty floors and dishes to not rolling socks up before putting them away.  

Check out more Daily Tones: https://t.co/KS6r6pRB8A

result.text:
A giant picture frame near Shanghai’s West Bund neighborhood is now one of the city’s most popular “check-in” spots. Designed by the artist Guo Xi to resemble a movie theater screen — complete with rolling captions — the installation has seemingly captured the imaginations of the city’s influencers. Guo has opened submissions for the text section, inviting contributors to share their own thoughts about time, space, architecture, or history.

Check out more Daily Tones: https://t.co/wXStIzeNkR

result.text:
Like a lot of iconic foods, there is an entire mythology about how gongbao jiding was invented. The best-known story revolves around Ding Baozhen, a Qing dynasty official who traveled around China performing his official duties while his retinue of cooks picked up new tastes and techniques at each stop.

Whether this origin story is true or not — there’s no particular evidence for or against it — it still does not tell us what an authentic version of the dish tastes like or how it should be made. Even if we could pinpoint the precise moment that gongbao jiding came into being, we still wouldn’t know how that first dish was made, much less how it actually tasted.

Read more: https://t.co/VSZ6ve425j

media.ext_alt_text: A map showing Ding Baozhen’s movements and how they might have contributed to the development of ‘gongbao jiding.’ Fu Xiaofan/Sixth Tone

result.text:
After 16 years of battling “demons,” one patient says he has been given a second chance at life by a brain-computer interface developed in Shanghai.

He feels he’s now able to manage his emotions and experience the vitality of life. Every night he goes to bed with one thought: What will tomorrow bring?

Read more: https://t.co/Nnc4w2mjZg
